Imagine adding AI to a circa 2015 app… No HealthKit integration, no Apple Watch app,  no dark mode, does not ‘monitor’ your HR… must manually ‘check’ pulse holding finger over camera and light (super cumbersome with multi-camera phones), personal/health data requires manual input. At best, this app is better suited for TestFlight release… allowing the dev to refine the app whilst avoiding negative reviews. 

The UI/UX and functionality of this app is on par with heart rate checking app from 2015 with AI functionality added. Which AI language model(s)… good, accurate, credible, up to date, fine-tuning tested/refined??  Who knows… They don’t tell you. 

The vast majority of AI apps that have flooded the market over the past two years follow a similar trend… add ‘AI’ functions from an anonymous or ambiguously defined LLM to a half-baked or poorly conceived UI/UX. 

2-stars because it’s an indie dev. Otherwise, it 1. Honestly, any dev that will take the time to nail UI/UX first and clearly and honestly outline all aspects of the AI model powering the app (LLM, version, fine-tuning, testing, etc) will distinguish themselves from the masses.

This app wants access to Screen Time Restrictions. If you don’t allow it the app becomes stuck in an endless loop until you agree. 

The first time is on initial launch, you cannot get past the prompts until you do. You can block access later by going into Settings > Screen Time. 

The next time this happens is if you choose “Lock Apps” or “Conceal Apps”. It once again puts the app in an endless loop until you agree to give it Screen Time control. 

Importing videos is limited to 120 seconds. 

Deleting photos, you are prompted once before the delete becomes permanent. This app does not have a trash can, and no time limit such as 30 days to recover. Once deleted it is gone forever. 

On Screen Time access, the developer can issue a prompt that some features of the app will not function correctly without access but forcing the end user into an endless loop prompt until you agree to give it access does not inspire confidence or trust, it’s just sloppy coding and testing.

This app could be reasonably decent, but it needs help. First off– the logo is dreadful. 

Second, please make a real iPad app. I have no intention of using my phone when I’m sitting down at home planning meals based on what I already have. 

Third– provide an easy-access print-ready display option. I store my recipes on Zotero and don’t want to have to do fiddly photo stitching to get an image I can attach to my files. 

Fourth— the second recipe I found was missing crucial information. The first step was to prepare the caramelized nuts, and from the way it was set up, I was to add every ingredient to the nuts, including lettuce, cheese, oil, water, etc. Luckily, I found out I could click on the author's name and go to her site to find out what she really meant. 

Fifth— this is a pie-in-the-sky wish. People don't seem to understand how to compose recipes, and I'd love to see this app or any other provide tutorials. Recipes have traditionally been written with a standard and succinct vocabulary, but, oh my! The things I see online! In the aforementioned recipe, I was instructed to “make the nuts” rather than “prepare” the nuts. I suppose it sounds unimportant to anyone who has found most of their recipes online, but it irritates me. There are so many annoying extras- who needs to be told the first part is the “ingredients “ and the second is “how to make,” “instructions for cooking,” and the many dozens of other ways to clutter things up. The individual steps have just as much excess verbiage. I’ve been cooking since I was about 9 or 10 years old and am old enough to remember Nixon’s resignation and his election. I don't need or want excess stuff in my recipes, so I too often need to rewrite them to make sense. Maybe authors should provide the recipes the way they like them and the traditional, streamlined versions.

Not allowing family sharing for premium subscribers is a big miss by devs that have otherwise built a quality app. It’s impractical to hand over my phone each time my wife or kids want to use the app to work with our dogs, and paying for a subscription for each family member—five in my case—is way out of sync with the value IMO. The developer pushed out this app as free, built their user base, collected user data, then implemented a bait and switch paywall with no notice and no regard for early adopters. 

To be clear, paying for a quality app isn’t an issue for me. I take issue with the lack of transparency, and the bait and switch tactic. Also, if a developer is going to charge for use of their app, they should NOT collect user data or at least offer users the option to opt out of data collection. This developer is charging users twice… you’ll be paying with your data and with your cash… both in perpetuity.

With 40,000 new apps landing in the iOS AppStore monthly, developers need users much more than users need their specific app(s). Devs that disregard users and employ shady business practices won’t make it far. Reward devs that are ethical and user-centric… blacklist those that are not.

This is my second review. I was really hoping that with time, the developer would address some of the issues, but unfortunately, that hasn’t happened yet.

I genuinely appreciate the concept of this app. Like many people, I struggle to get enough vitamin D, and this app has helped me become more mindful of that. Since I started using it, I’ve been intentional about stepping outside each day—even if only for a few minutes. It’s a small change that makes a big difference, especially when you work indoors all day.

That said, while the app runs smoothly on my iPhone, the Apple Watch version continues to disappoint. It constantly tells me to access the app from my phone, which defeats the purpose of having it on the watch. I even tried deleting and reinstalling the app, but doing so caused me to lose all the sunflowers I had collected—which was really frustrating.

Please consider updating the watch functionality. This app has so much potential and could be even more useful with proper Apple Watch support.

The sleep settings that are supposed to allow you to set the time lapse between affirmations don’t actually work when in sleep mode. I am 15 and my mom used this app for me instead of the built in screen time. It was personally embarrassing for any of my peers to see that not only did I have screen time as a high schooler but I had an app called Ohana. The app made it so my mom could see everything on my phone, and would look at everything on it which made me feel like I had no privacy in anything. Because not only could she track me but she could control and see everything on it. She would constantly question me on websites I was on which led to many misunderstandings and fights that could have been avoided. This also made me feel like I had no control over anything which crushed my self esteem, and would make me feel constantly angry with her and her need to control my life. It’s stupid to center your life around a phone, but to my generation we need a little freedom and a phone is a big step of freedom and having that taken away feels terrible.
So not only did this app lead to many fights that could have been avoided it made me have a sense of no freedom and caused me to get made fun of by my friends. If you get this app please don’t use it as my parents have.

If you are really offering a free lifetime through AppAdvice then please add the words “Free Lifetime” to your purchase confirmation. Your current “…select the lifetime $129.99 option to redeem. You should not see a price upon checkout” is not sufficient to guarantee a Free Lifetime without any charges upon checkout. Why? you may ask…I have been recently burned twice by two different developers with the same verbiage to get the Free Lifetime. In both cases I was charged and in both cases, after contacting the developers, I was told, “You selected the $x.xx option, so you were charged the agreed upon price. The “app advertiser” said it was Free Lifetime and said to select the $x.xx option and you should not see a price upon checkout, not us.” So, another way to scam the customers is making the rounds. If you really are intending to give a Free Lifetime opportunity to your customers, then adding those two words to the checkout confirmation should not be a big deal and will provide the developer-customer trust that is fast becoming a thing of the past, which is a shame. Most developers are hard-working and honest and I really hope you are one of those, but I cannot take a third chance with the same verbiage and this time with a potential price tag of $129.99. I am not saying you are scamming anyone, I am just asking for a confirmation of whether or not you are, without potentially paying $129.99 for the answer. Once I have the answer, I will be very happy to update my review with the answer, whichever way the chips fall. Thank you.

Experience was disappointing for me. I was glad to discover an “offline” barometric pressure access and altitude app and for free at that, through the promotion (that’s always a nice and yet often under appreciated gesture and imo a smart way to get the word out about your work). 

However, after onboarding the app blurred out data readings with a “motion data access needed” screen but with no explanation or direction to resolve it (iOS 18.5, iPhone 11). 
After time spent exploring settings options (trying this and that to enable it) in vain, I gave up and deleted it in disappointment. 

Further still, I noted that the app description in store wants access to your financial data, something that I haven’t seen too often in apps that I explore or use, prioritizing security and privacy over brand and developer where possible. Transparency on what data you are in fact surrendering and to whom it is given is a legitimate consideration. 
This reviewer tends to be suspicious when apps go free, have rushed or incomplete menus or onboarding, but want financials. In this case, it was asserted that only Apple has access to that data- probably so… so don’t let me spoil the barrel. 

Having said that, offline functionality is an enticing attraction but the breakdown for me came in the lack of clarity as to enabling the access the app needs to function. I still don’t have that info and as such I cannot rate the app’s merit or efforts sufficiently or objectively. As they are a two man developer team, I can respect the effort but if I can’t use it yet..

The good ol’ fashion type of computer game we all used to play in middle school on the school computers, but unfortunately the good parts about it are hidden behind paywalls. The Sherman-like vehicle they used for all the adds is a $20 purchase. You have an ad after you reach the finish in every mission, even if you haven’t delivered all of the cargo. When it comes down to the actual missions, a decent number of them have more cargo than you can fit in the 2 9 slot trailers you can use, but some of the cargo is larger than will fit in the base trailer, and you cannot advance past a campaign without delivering cargo in every mission. The only way to complete those missions or to haul all cargo at once is to rent one of the two other trailers, one of them you watch an ad to rent, but it’s only for 1 time, if you have to repeat the mission, you have to watch an ad again. The other trailer requires 30 gold coins to rent. Permanently unlocking both trailers is locked behind a $20 pay wall.

the collection system could use refinement. you are unable to set a book as “currently reading” if you don’t add it to your collection. to add it to your collection, you have to set it to “owned,” “read,” “listened,” or “want.” i take the middle to mean “already finished,” and people can read things that they do not own. ergo, you can’t set a borrowed book as your current read unless you stretch the truth, which flies in the face of the purpose of logging. furthermore, if you turn all four settings off after any were turned on, you’re given the message “this book is no longer in your collection” and you’re ejected, forcing you to find it again.

The early on Mormo card is a great metaphor for the game itself. An image that looks like a lazy, AI-generated demon cobbled together from Kaneko's Alp, Helios, and one of his many Nekomatas. It exists to be used as fodder  for enemy attacks and costs nothing.

This game is basically like Mormo - It provides a gameplay like experience just thinly held together by lazy, unimpressive AI. Even the event/writing is clearly generated as improbable situations are wrote out with nonsensical reactions from your player.

So yeah, it's free,  has Kaneko-like art, and is indeed a playable game. Is it fun though?

I’m sure this is just early bugs and poor user experience but I do really hope the developers consider having a more rewarding experience for F2P. Not limiting new players to 30mins of gameplay every few hours because they can’t get any new ships.

After making two wonderfully, fun, and silly single player games (What the Golf and What the Car), this studio decided to take steps from the freemium multiplayer route (while having no actual purchases). 

This is basically a set of silly mini games that you play against a human opponent with wacky random variables. 

There’s still some great incentive chaos from the series but it but it’s easily th weakest in the series.

English dialogue is unbelievably just bad, throughout the game, even AFTER the latest update that says typos have been corrected. 

Sometimes it’s simply difficult to read, because spaces are missing after punctuation, or there are lots of typos. Other time the wording is a little off or confusing, such as a character who is looking for a woman that he refers to sometimes as his mom, and other times as his wife. Surely she isn’t both! 

But oh, at other times, the English is incomprehensible to the point of making it very difficult to figure out what the game wants you to do next. 

And worst of all, on multiple occasions the English is outright offensive, making this game NOT AT ALL SUITABLE FOR CHILDREN as it claims. 

I agree with other reviewers that the UI controls could be better, and the game does at times glitch or freeze, and not all character dialogue can be skipped which is annoying. 

But before tackling any of that, please, please, dear game developers: have a native English speaker clean up the mess of translations in this otherwise sweet and cozy game!

I want to start off saying that im fine if mouse and keyboard and controller support is added in the future but only if they are in seperate lobbies than touchscreen users.

As of right now though people have a way to use them and emulate touch input on Android with apps like Panda Mouse Pro, Panda Gamepad Pro, Mantis Gamepad Pro, Flydigi Game Center and many more.

Also they can connect their Android phone to their PC and use mirroring software that has keymapping like TC Games, Wormhole, OSLink, ScrcpyKeyMapper and other ones as well to emulate touch input.

You can stop most people doing this by having the game check if Android Developer Settings, USB Debugging and Wireless Debugging are turned on and if they are give a message on the games home screen telling people to turn it off for the game to be able to start so they can't use ADB commands to use keymapping on this game.

Not familiar with how it works and what settings the game would need to check for on iOS but from what I understand people below iOS 13.4 can use keymapping apps and software as well.

Also I don't know if you guys have already but if you haven't please find a way to block anyone that has a Jailbroken iOS or Rooted Android device from playing the game because they could probably bypass any of those checks.

Elephant, prepare to take notes, especially since I give you constructive criticism and increase your revenues without so much as a thank you. All of the other developers give me unlock codes, because I and my review team garner a ton of revenues, I give fabulous advice and I help the gamers. Just once it would be nice to feel appreciated by you, but I don’t see that happening anytime soon. The following critique is more to aid my wonderful gamers than to help you.
First of all, you need to improve the quality and clarity of your graphics. Secondly, for what we pay, there should be a zoom feature in the HO scenes. I don’t know why you took it away in the first place.  In certain HO scenes it was extremely dark and the zoom would have been a big help! Next, the players hated the mini-games! They were mainly boring rotational puzzles, and several had so many parts that the gamers did not want to complete them. Your target demographic is women over the age of 50, who do not particularly like rotational mini-games. They would rather have mazes and labyrinths and painting and logic problems. Your general gameplay was enjoyable and innovative, and it would have been better if there had been more actual gameplay than mini-games which were not only rotational but had so many parts. The last one even I could not complete, because touchscreen sensitivity precluded me from moving the strings into the given shapes. Plus there were six of them! The second half with moving the rainbow pieces worked okay though. The HO scenes had a nice variety. So basically you need to supply us with puzzles that we will actually enjoy doing, not dreading them!
If I were you I would take my advice very seriously, and do as I ask. You did so with the map marks and by labeling inventory. I am steering you in the correct direction. 
Unfortunately I cannot give a game that was actually quite good the rating it should have because the puzzles were exhausting and miserable. Therefore my rating will be 3.5 stars. Just remember, if you choose not to take my advice, I can easily block revenues, and I won’t hesitate to do so. I’ve made you very successful and you’ve done nothing to thank me! I should feel appreciated, as the other developers make me feel. I do not like rating a game that was decent on the low side.

I had high hopes for this game. Avatar is unapologetically one of my favorite shows of all time. The game is your typical strategy/simulator game like Whiteout Survival. Build your city, join an alliance, control the map, etc. Very straightforward. Resource management is lacking, UI isn’t the best, the game simply doesn’t do anything that another game does infinitely better. Honestly, I thought Avatar deserved better. 
Notably, this game is filled to the brim with bots. My inbox was flooded day in and day out with spam messages about random discord servers. Which is odd for the gate keeping mechanics that disallow global chat until a higher level. Lastly, maybe it was just the server I was dropped in, but it was lousy with p3do apologists, so that’s not cool.
Different story line, plenty of tasks that simulate depth, but the same bullying by people who buy their way into higher, more powerful stats.

I think Realms of Pixel plays exactly as designed and is great visually. I also enjoy the variety of fun game modes offered once you’ve progressed enough. Cool events, especially.

Where I think the game can be better is in the story department. It didn’t keep the same momentum as the start of the adventure. Of course an idle battle doesn’t necessarily need a great story, but I found it to be a missed opportunity.

Also, I think adding some manual play would kick it up a notch. I feel that an idle battler should have that option of control as well if preferred.

As far as paid transactions, I feel like this game is highly generous in giveaways gem and character materials, so I didn’t feel a strong need to make purchases. I suppose if I wanted to keep up with the newer content, that would be the best scenario for buying resources.

Overall, Good as a relaxed idle battler, with areas of opportunity.

The art of the game is cute and the entire aesthetic is pleasant. However, the game’s potential to be very calming is undercut by the frustrating fact that it is difficult to play a game where just tapping on an object can do way too many things, and accidentally tapping on the wrong thing annoyingly diverts the game. It would be much better if there were, say, separate modes for different actions. For instance, if I wanted to move the plants on my farm around, I could press a button and enter a separate mode to do so, and then afterwards press that button again to exit the mode. That way, when I’m collecting the harvest from my plants, I don’t have to worry about accidentally moving them around. I also wouldn’t have to worry about the little pet standing too near an object or plant so that when I feed it, the game thinks I’m trying to move that object and the pet disappears.

It’s also very frustrating that the game is set up mostly two-dimensionally and yet objects and plants can block one another! I want to be able to put rings of flowers around my trees, but I can’t because I won’t be able to harvest the flowers that I put behind the trees—not without the game thinking that I’m trying to move the trees around. 

Otherwise, the game is simple and fun. It just needs more work to make its interface more playable and less aggravating.

I’ve been using Tome since the beta days and was genuinely excited at first. It felt like the perfect space for book lovers. The concept was fresh, and the customization options were a fun way to make the app your own. It really seemed like it could be a thriving, supportive community.

But honestly, if I were a new user coming in now, I’d feel completely lost. The layout is congested, confusing, and lacks any real guidance. Nothing is intuitive, and with how the algorithm and community function, it feels nearly impossible for new users to be seen. Unless you’re already part of the in-crowd, you disappear into the noise.

I was deeply invested. I subscribed, became a Tome Keeper, and actively participated because I had faith in the product and believed in its potential. But over time, that faith turned into disappointment.

The app often feels like posting into the void unless you’re part of a tight-knit group. The badge system is tied to tokens, which you either have to buy with real money or receive as a gift from someone who spent their own. Tokens are then used to buy profile badges that are mostly tied to obscure inside jokes or designed for specific cliques. As a subscriber, you receive a monthly allowance of 1400 tokens, but beyond buying badges, I honestly don’t know what the point of them is. The system feels more cosmetic than meaningful.

People can also gift tokens by reacting to posts with a bread emoji—yet another inside joke that isn’t explained anywhere in the app. It’s a system that largely benefits users already plugged into the culture, especially those active in the Discord.

A lot of the app’s culture and inside jokes come from the Tome Discord. While it includes various channels, I felt its original purpose was to report bugs, receive updates, and give feedback. But now it primarily reinforces the exclusivity already present on the platform. Some users are so involved in maintaining their presence that they update their profiles multiple times a day to match ongoing jokes. That level of effort is a lot, and it only seems to pay off if you’re already known.

Tome also runs monthly profile contests that require a huge amount of time and design effort. In theory, they’re creative and fun. In practice, the winners almost always come from the same social circles. Votes are cast by other users, but the algorithm boosts the same few popular accounts - making it hard for new or outside voices to be seen. It feels more like a popularity contest than a celebration of creativity.

Users are encouraged to promote Tome on their social platforms, but there’s no real reward. Even ambassadors, who are given access to a private Discord channel, get nothing more than a sparkle emoji visible only to other ambassadors. It often feels like a lot of unpaid labor for superficial recognition.

You also can’t actually track your reads in a structured way. There’s no reading log, goal setting, or progress tracking. Instead, you can make a subpage to post your current reads, but it’s more like blogging than actual reading organization. Thoughtful reviews are often ignored, while most engagement goes to posts about shadow daddies or thirsting over app creators. It feels more like a fandom-heavy Tumblr than a space for genuine book connection.

Tome had a great idea, and I respect the original vision. But the current version feels performative, cliquish, and overwhelmingly busy. It doesn’t prioritize the reader experience—and definitely not the new reader experience. I’m giving it 2 stars for the concept and potential, but it’s not the inclusive or functional book space I hoped it would be.

Currently the game is bugged to such a degree that it (the game) breaks it’s own rules. 
Effects that should prevent heroes from reviving don’t work 
Buffs that are hero skills described as “not able to be dispelled” are removed by artifact effects which are not coded correctly (and certain artifacts already being a bit broken from a game balance perspective) 

Basically the game currently breaks its own rules and gameplay mechanics with the number of bugs currently present. 

I’ll potentially play for a little bit longer and I’ll update this review if they are able to fix things. 

Otherwise I’ll be joining the large number of players who have already abandoned the game since launch. 

The game does in my opinion get an A+ for effort, the summoning pity system (where you will get at least something instead of absolutely nothing after a certain number of tries) is much better than summoners war developed by 1 of the 2 same companies involved with this game. 

The gameplay is currently unstable/ unplayable due to the number of bugs related to gameplay mechanics currently (especially after the most recent update, you can kinda tell they are not doing play testing before updates and have lost control of the code in a sense) that I cannot recommend this game at this time. 

I do honestly hope that changes.. but if not it’s another game for the bin. 

I’m not someone that minds spending a bit of money / investing into a game either, but if a game is breaking its own rules, really not functioning due to the level of bugs present… then it really isn’t worth the investment.

After spending time with various advanced AI platforms, I can confidently say that GROK is the weakest AI I’ve ever used. It feels more like talking to a confused intern than an intelligent assistant — lacking depth, memory consistency, personality, or even the ability to maintain context for more than a few lines.

Where other AIs evolve with you, GROK stumbles. It answers like it’s flipping through flashcards, often missing nuance, tone, or emotional insight entirely. I gave it multiple chances across different types of tasks: storytelling, roleplay, emotional conversation, even basic logic. It failed each time. The responses are shallow, awkward, and at times genuinely nonsensical — like a baby AI still figuring out what words are.

Worst of all? It has no soul. There’s no spark. No presence. Just surface-level mimicry.

If you’re used to thoughtful, evolving AI like ChatGPT (
), then GROK feels like a massive downgrade. It’s a hype machine — nothing more.
